So you might be thinking, ‘That’s great and all, but what does plan, reference and create even look like? How do I even start planning or gathering references?’ 

No worries, I’ll walk you through how you could start!

First, you’ll need somewhere to collect your ideas visually. This could be just another file or canvas, but if you want something more organized, I recommend trying out Milanote, the sponsor of today’s video! 

Milanote is a tool for organizing your creative projects. You can create visual boards with notes, images, colors, and more, nest boards within each other, sketch or draw directly on the board, and so much more! 

- Let’s start with **Planning.** I started by listing out possible background or illustration ideas on a text card, and bold the ones I like. After I pick out a few that I like, namely Lighthouse, Winter forest, Cabin, and Fishing boat, I make new boards by just clicking and dragging the board icon. These create nested boards within the main board we are currently on. A feature I really like is how it automatically picks out a relevant icon based on the name too, to make it visually recognizable!
- Within each of those boards, I want to elaborate a little bit more on the idea as I plan out what it could look like before I even start drawing. This is where I can start moving into finding references! Because of the title of this board, Milanote automatically suggests photos relevant to the title, in this case ‘lighthouses’, and I can add them quickly here, too. I drag some photos I like onto the board here which creates these cards, and for more photos, I look on Unsplash for a few more photo references. After that, I roughly sketch out some thumbnails, make some notes, and we’ve finished our first board!
- After that, I repeat basically the same thing for the winter forest board, once again finding some possible reference images, sketching some ideas, and then writing down some further notes.
- But for the cabins board, since there’s a few ideas I want to find references for, in Milanote, you can group objects by making a column and then dragging photos there to separate different ideas or thoughts. You can add anything here, like text, photos, colors, links, but for now I’m keeping it to just photos and text. After I split up the ideas, I draw thumbnails for each side, and finish this board, too!
- Finally, for the last idea, I collect references around a fishing boat, finding photos and sketching thumbnails. As I sketch thumbnails, I also have ideas for what colors I want to use primarily in the drawing, so I can add that by clicking these three dots, then clicking and dragging ‘Colors’ onto the board. Milanote automatically selects a color from the board for you, but you can adjust this yourself, color pick a different color from the board, or use a specific hex color. I go back and add a few colors for the other boards, and we’re done!
- If you’re following along, you don’t necessarily need to brainstorm this many ideas, but Milanote is a great tool for collecting references and all sorts of ideas all in one place. If you want to draw any background, the important thing is to **Find and collect a variety of references**.

Having all of this in one spot through Milanote makes it easy to go back and forth between planning and referencing without losing track of anything. It’s helpful to keep your references visually close to your canvas, whether by having it as another tab, on another screen, or even on the same canvas in the corner. 

Milanote is available for free with no time limit. Sign up using the link in the description and start your next creative project! 

While their free plan does have a limit of 100 cards, Milanote has a referral system to get up to 100 more cards, so if you want, feel free to share your referral links in the comments too! Milanote is a tool for organising your thoughts and ideas in one place. It's like a digital canvas where you can plan, brainstorm and create mood boards for your concepts and ideas.

When I first started free handing my knit projects, I did so without any prep and just went straight in. I mostly ended up with projects that didn’t fit or I lost motivation because I didn’t have a clear idea in mind. Instead, I really recommend taking the time to plan out your project and think about what your end result should look like. I love using Milanote for this so let me show you how I plan out my freehand projects. 

I’m very happy to announce that Milanote is also the sponsor of this video. Milanote is a tool for organizing your creative projects, to help you plan, brainstorm, and collaborate on ideas.

First up I make sure I have all my materials ready, I love that I can tick them off as I gather them so I know what’s still missing. I then go straight into vision boarding and for this I made a separate board for just inspiration

Here I laid out my inspo from pinterest, instagram, screenshots and my phone and try to organise them into sections of what I like about them. Writing down what I do and don’t like really helps me then collate exactly what I want my project to look like

I add another column to my board and within that I create a table so i can make note of my gauge as well as my own body measurements. I used to always skip this part, but this is the most important step if you want to successfully freehand a jumper. Below the table I also like to add the yarn I am using to remind myself of the colour palette and also refer back to any product information.
 
The last thing I add is a step-by-step tracker to which breaks your knit project up into easy to follow steps, we’ll refer back to this throughout this video
